Twists of cohomology theories

Jun 15, 2019

The goal of this post is to describe twistings of equivariant cohomology theories. Let us first recall in modern language how twistings work: suppose is an -ring, and let be a spectrum. Suppose that there is a map . If is a space and is a cohomology class, then we obtain the twisted -cohomology of , twisted by , defined as . Similarly, the twisted -homology of is .

It is not hard to build twists of interesting cohomology theories. Take, for instance, , and ; then there is a map , and so we can twist K-theory by classes in . This is classical. One overblown way to construct this map is by considering the map given by the J-homomorphism. Composing with the map gives a null map, thanks to the Atiyah-Bott-Shapiro orientation of . It follows that the map from factors through ; in particular, we obtain a map from the fiber of to . This map is an infinite loop map, so we in fact obtain an infinite loop map . Via the twisting map for , we obtain a map . (One could alternatively view the existence of this twisting map and the J-homomorphism as providing the -orientation of .)

We can also do this with : there’s a map given by the J-homomorphism, and composing with gives a null map, thanks to the String orientation of tmf. We therefore get a map from the fiber of to . This map is an infinite loop map, so we in fact obtain a map . (I want to make a remark about a cute fact here: the composite detects . This is related to our first post about Hodge theory and .)

Work of Westerland generalizes this, at least -locally; Theorem 1.2 in this paper produces an -map . This is adjoint to a map , which in fact deloops to a spectrum map .

We view as the geometric realization of the Picard -groupoid of the nerve . Define an -category of compactly generated -linear -categories (see here); then is (this isn’t technically correct: the Picard space is actually , but we’ll ignore this distinction in this post.), and so there’s an infinite loop map . We can therefore try to define the twisting map for via a functor which restricts to a morphism of Picard spaces (this would be implied by the functor being symmetric monoidal, but it isn’t a necessary condition).

Suppose is a compactly generated -linear category (if we incorporate a -action everywhere, we’ll obtain the twisting map for ). Define a spectrum as the base-change of the algebraic K-theory spectrum of the -category of compact objects in . If (with the complex conjugation action), then this defines (resp. ). Moreover, since admits the structure of a -equivariant -module, we find that is a -module. This defines a (lax monoidal) functor , which defines the claimed twisting map for . (To observe that this is the same twisting map as in the classical case, we can use this paper: essentially all we have to observe is that , the identity in , is hit, which is obvious by construction.) Similarly, we obtain -equivariant twisting maps for every compact Lie group , and hence a map ; this gives a map .

Note that the construction described above also provides for any ring spectrum a functor , and hence a functor . This corresponds to a map , whose construction at the space level is well-known (see Definition 1.7 here). If is an algebraically closed field, this further determines a functor to the Picard space , so we can twist the algebraic K-theory of algebraically closed fields by classes of .

Can we similarly describe the map explicitly? In the above description, we relied heavily upon a concrete description of what classifies, as well as the existence of a nice algebraic K-theory functor. We may hypothesize that classifies invertible objects in the -category of “Azumaya” -linear cocomplete -categories. We then need to be able to define a “higher algebraic K-theory” functor which sends such a to an object of . I don’t know how to define such a “higher” algebraic K-theory spectrum. It should take category level to chromatic height , so it’s certainly doing something interesting… This also seems to be related to the perspective that classifies -vector bundles.

Part of the reason this would be very interesting stems from the equivariant generalization of the twisting map in the case of K-theory. Suppose that we could construct an equivariant map for every . (I only know how to define for compact abelian, but as usual, interesting things begin to happen in the nonabelian case. Let’s ignore this issue for now.) This should then define a map . In particular, each map should define an invertible -module. Mathew-Meier implies that , where is the universal oriented derived elliptic curve. We therefore get a line bundle over . The construction of this line bundle has been known for a while (at least complex analytically), and it is related to moonshine.

Of course, one can similarly ask for an explicit description of the map , but this seems equally, if not more, mysterious than the case of . Following the discussion above, this general map seems to be related to the construction of a “higher” algebraic K-theory spectrum which takes category level to chromatic height .

And then, of course, there’s the relationship with Dijkgraaf-Witten theory. To each element of , we can define an -dimensional extended TQFT, and also an element of , where is the universal oriented deformation of a height formal group over a perfect field of characteristic . In particular, it might be possible to construct an -dimensional extended TQFT (defined on manifolds with some extra structure) associated to a line bundle over .
